_**Ant-Man**_ is a 2015 American [superhero film](/wiki/Superhero_film
"Superhero film") based on the [Marvel Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel
Comics") characters [of the same name](/wiki/Ant-Man "Ant-Man"): [Scott
Lang](/wiki/Ant-Man_\(Scott_Lang\) "Ant-Man \(Scott Lang\)") and [Hank
Pym](/wiki/Hank_Pym "Hank Pym"). Produced by [Marvel
Studios](/wiki/Marvel_Studios "Marvel Studios") and distributed by [Walt
Disney Studios Motion Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Motion_Pictures
"Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures"), it is [the twelfth
film](/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films "List of Marvel Cinematic
Universe films") in the [Marvel Cinematic
Universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic Universe") (MCU).
The film was directed by [Peyton Reed](/wiki/Peyton_Reed "Peyton Reed"), with
a screenplay by the writing teams of [Edgar Wright](/wiki/Edgar_Wright "Edgar
Wright") and [Joe Cornish](/wiki/Joe_Cornish "Joe Cornish"), and [Adam
McKay](/wiki/Adam_McKay "Adam McKay") and [Paul Rudd](/wiki/Paul_Rudd "Paul
Rudd"). It stars Rudd as Scott Lang / Ant-Man, alongside [Evangeline
Lilly](/wiki/Evangeline_Lilly "Evangeline Lilly"), [Corey
Stoll](/wiki/Corey_Stoll "Corey Stoll"), [Bobby
Cannavale](/wiki/Bobby_Cannavale "Bobby Cannavale"), [Michael
Peña](/wiki/Michael_Pe%C3%B1a "Michael Peña"), [Tip "T.I." Harris](/wiki/T.I.
"T.I."), [Anthony Mackie](/wiki/Anthony_Mackie "Anthony Mackie"), [Wood
Harris](/wiki/Wood_Harris "Wood Harris"), [Judy Greer](/wiki/Judy_Greer "Judy
Greer"), [David Dastmalchian](/wiki/David_Dastmalchian "David Dastmalchian"),
and [Michael Douglas](/wiki/Michael_Douglas "Michael Douglas") as Hank Pym. In
_Ant-Man_ , Lang must help defend Pym's Ant-Man shrinking technology and plot
a heist with worldwide ramifications.

Development of _Ant-Man_ began in April 2006, with the hiring of Wright to
direct and co-write with Cornish. By April 2011, Wright and Cornish had
completed three drafts of the script and Wright shot test footage for the film
in July 2012. Pre-production began in October 2013 after being put on hold so
that Wright could complete _[The World's End](/wiki/The_World%27s_End_\(film\)
"The World's End \(film\)")_. Casting began in December 2013, with the hiring
of Rudd to play Lang. In May 2014, Wright left the project, citing creative
differences, though he still received screenplay and story credits with
Cornish, as well as an executive producer credit. The following month, Reed
was brought in to replace Wright, while McKay was hired to contribute to the
script with Rudd. Principal photography took place between August and December
2014 in San Francisco and [Metro Atlanta](/wiki/Atlanta_metropolitan_area
"Atlanta metropolitan area").

_Ant-Man_ held its world premiere in Los Angeles on June 29, 2015, and was
released in the United States on July 17, 2015, in [3D](/wiki/3D_film "3D
film") and [IMAX 3D](/wiki/IMAX_3D "IMAX 3D"). Upon its release, the film
grossed more than $519 million worldwide, and received positive reviews from
critics, who generally welcomed the film's smaller stakes than preceding MCU
installments, as well as its cast, humor, and CGI sequences. A sequel, titled
_[Ant-Man and the Wasp](/wiki/Ant-Man_and_the_Wasp "Ant-Man and the Wasp")_ ,
is scheduled to be released on July 6, 2018.

## Plot[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Plot")]

In 1989, scientist [Hank Pym](/wiki/Hank_Pym "Hank Pym") resigns from
[S.H.I.E.L.D.](/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D. "S.H.I.E.L.D.") after discovering their
attempt to replicate his [Ant-Man](/wiki/Ant-Man "Ant-Man") shrinking
technology. Believing the technology is dangerous, Pym vows to hide it as long
as he lives.

In the present day,[N 1] Pym's estranged daughter, [Hope van
Dyne](/wiki/Hope_Pym "Hope Pym"), and former protégé, [Darren
Cross](/wiki/Darren_Cross "Darren Cross"), have forced him out of his company,
Pym Technologies. Cross is close to perfecting a shrinking suit of his own,
the [Yellowjacket](/wiki/Yellowjacket_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Yellowjacket \(Marvel
Comics\)"), which horrifies Pym.

Upon his release from prison, well-meaning thief [Scott Lang](/wiki/Ant-
Man_\(Scott_Lang\) "Ant-Man \(Scott Lang\)") moves in with his old cellmate,
Luis. Lang visits his daughter [Cassie](/wiki/Cassandra_Lang "Cassandra Lang")
unannounced and is chastised by his former wife Maggie and her police-
detective fiancé, Paxton, for not providing child support. Unable to hold a
job because of his criminal record, Lang agrees to join Luis' crew and commit
a burglary. Lang breaks into a house and cracks its safe, but only finds what
he believes to be an old motorcycle suit, which he takes home. After trying
the suit on, Lang accidentally shrinks himself to the size of an insect.
Terrified by the experience, he returns the suit to the house, but is arrested
on the way out. Pym, the homeowner, visits Lang in jail and smuggles the suit
into his cell to help him break out.

Pym, who manipulated Lang through an unknowing Luis into stealing the suit as
a test, wants Lang to become the new Ant-Man to steal the Yellowjacket from
Cross. Having been spying on Cross after discovering his intentions, van Dyne
and Pym train Lang to fight and to control ants. While van Dyne harbors
resentment towards Pym about her mother Janet's death, he reveals that Janet,
known as the [Wasp](/wiki/Wasp_\(comics\) "Wasp \(comics\)"), disappeared into
a subatomic [quantum
realm](/wiki/Features_of_the_Marvel_Universe#Extradimensional_places "Features
of the Marvel Universe") while disabling a [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet_Union "Soviet
Union") nuclear missile. Pym warns Lang that he could suffer a similar fate if
he overrides his suit's regulator. They send him to steal a device that will
aid their heist from the [Avengers](/wiki/Avengers_\(comics\) "Avengers
\(comics\)")' headquarters, where he briefly fights [Sam
Wilson](/wiki/Falcon_\(comics\) "Falcon \(comics\)").

Cross perfects the Yellowjacket and hosts an unveiling ceremony at Pym
Technologies' headquarters. Lang, along with his crew and a swarm of flying
ants, infiltrates the building during the event, sabotages the company's
[servers](/wiki/Server_\(computing\) "Server \(computing\)"), and plants
explosives. When he attempts to steal the Yellowjacket, he, along with Pym and
Hope, are captured by Cross, who intends to sell both the Yellowjacket and
Ant-Man suits to [Hydra](/wiki/Hydra_\(comics\) "Hydra \(comics\)"). Lang
breaks free and he and Hope dispatch most of the Hydra agents, though one
flees with a vial of Cross' particles and Pym is shot. Lang pursues Cross,
while the explosives detonate, imploding the building as Pym and van Dyne
escape.

Cross dons the Yellowjacket and attacks Lang before Lang is arrested by
Paxton. Cross takes Cassie hostage to lure Lang into another fight. Lang
overrides the regulator and shrinks to subatomic size to penetrate Cross' suit
and sabotage it to shrink uncontrollably, killing Cross. Lang disappears into
the quantum realm but manages to reverse the effects and returns to the
[macroscopic](/wiki/Macroscopic_scale "Macroscopic scale") world. Out of
gratitude for Lang's heroism, Paxton covers for Lang to keep him out of
prison. Seeing that Lang survived and returned from the quantum realm, Pym
wonders if his wife is alive as well. Later, Lang meets up with Luis, who
tells him that Wilson is looking for him.

In a mid-credits scene, Pym shows van Dyne a new Wasp prototype suit and
offers it to her. In a [post-credits scene](/wiki/Post-credits_scene "Post-
credits scene"), Wilson and [Steve Rogers](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain
America") have [Bucky Barnes](/wiki/Bucky_Barnes "Bucky Barnes") in their
custody. Unable to contact [Tony Stark](/wiki/Iron_Man "Iron Man") because of
"[the accords](/wiki/Registration_acts_\(comics\)#Marvel_Cinematic_Universe
"Registration acts \(comics\)")",[N 2] Wilson mentions that he knows someone
who can help.

## Cast[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Cast")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Ant-
Man_SDCC_2014_panel.jpg/220px-Ant-Man_SDCC_2014_panel.jpg)](/wiki/File:Ant-
Man_SDCC_2014_panel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Ant-Man_SDCC_2014_panel.jpg "Enlarge")

(L-R) Peyton Reed (director), Paul Rudd, Michael Douglas, Evangeline Lilly,
and Corey Stoll at the 2014 [San Diego Comic-Con](/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-
Con_International "San Diego Comic-Con International")

  * [Paul Rudd](/wiki/Paul_Rudd "Paul Rudd") as [Scott Lang / Ant-Man](/wiki/Ant-Man_\(Scott_Lang\) "Ant-Man \(Scott Lang\)"):  
A former systems engineer at VistaCorp and petty criminal who acquires a suit
that allows him to shrink in size but increase in strength.[5][6][7][8][9]
Regarding Rudd's casting, producer Kevin Feige said, "Look at that origin of
the petty crook who comes into contact with a suit and does his best to make
good, and then look at someone like Paul Rudd, who can do slightly unsavory
things like break into people's houses and still be charming and who you root
for and whose redemption you will find satisfaction in."[6] Director [Peyton
Reed](/wiki/Peyton_Reed "Peyton Reed") compared Lang to [George
Clooney](/wiki/George_Clooney "George Clooney")'s character [Danny
Ocean](/wiki/Danny_Ocean_\(character\) "Danny Ocean \(character\)") from
_[Ocean's Eleven](/wiki/Ocean%27s_Eleven "Ocean's Eleven")_, saying, "He's a
guy trying to create a new life for himself and find redemption." To get in
shape for the role, Rudd worked with trainers and cut alcohol, fried foods,
and carbohydrates out of his diet.[10] Rudd stated that in preparation for his
role, he "basically didn't eat anything for about a year ... I took the [Chris
Pratt](/wiki/Chris_Pratt "Chris Pratt") approach to training for an action
movie. Eliminate anything fun for a year and then you can play a hero."[11]
Rudd signed a multi-film contract with Marvel, with Feige saying it was "three
[films]-plus-plus to appear in other things."[12]

  * [Evangeline Lilly](/wiki/Evangeline_Lilly "Evangeline Lilly") as [Hope van Dyne](/wiki/Hope_Pym "Hope Pym"):  
The daughter of Hank Pym and [Janet van Dyne](/wiki/Wasp_\(comics\) "Wasp
\(comics\)") and a senior board member of Pym Technologies, who helps Darren
Cross take over the company.[13][14][15][16][17] Throughout the film,
character progression brings Hope closer to becoming a hero.[18] Lilly
described her character as "capable, strong, and kick-ass", but said that
being raised by two superheroes resulted in Hope being "a pretty screwed up
human being... and the clear message sent by my name is that I'm not a big fan
of my father and so I took my mother's name."[19] She added that van Dyne's
"arc in the movie is trying to find a relationship" with Pym.[10] Originally
cast by Wright, Lilly was reluctant to take the role after he left the project
until she read the revised script and got a chance to meet with Reed.[15]
Feige said that van Dyne was the more obvious choice to take up the mantle of
Ant-Man, being "infinitely more capable of actually being a superhero" than
Lang, and that the reason she does not is because of Pym's experience with
losing her mother, rather than sexism, which Feige felt would not be a problem
for Pym in modern times. Lilly signed a multi-film contract with Marvel.[20]

  * [Corey Stoll](/wiki/Corey_Stoll "Corey Stoll") as [Darren Cross](/wiki/Darren_Cross "Darren Cross") / [Yellowjacket](/wiki/Yellowjacket_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Yellowjacket \(Marvel Comics\)"):  
A former protégé of Pym's, who takes over his mentor's company and militarizes
a similar version of the Ant-Man technology to create the Yellowjacket
suit.[14][16][21][22] Stoll described the suit as "the next generation of Ant-
Man's suit", with a sleeker, more militaristic look as "if
[Apple](/wiki/Apple_Inc. "Apple Inc.") had designed a battle suit."[23] As for
his character, Stoll said that Cross was more like Hank Pym than
"[Thanos](/wiki/Thanos "Thanos") or [Loki](/wiki/Loki_\(comics\) "Loki
\(comics\)"), who are villains that know it", since Cross is a "brilliant
scientist, who is not ethically pure" with shades of gray.[24] Unlike Rudd,
who wore a practical costume as Ant-Man, Stoll wore a [motion
capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion capture") suit while performing as
Yellowjacket. Reed explained that this decision was made early on when
creating and filming with a real Yellowjacket costume was found to be
impractical.[25]

  * [Bobby Cannavale](/wiki/Bobby_Cannavale "Bobby Cannavale") as Paxton:  
A [San Francisco Police Department](/wiki/San_Francisco_Police_Department "San
Francisco Police Department") officer who is engaged to Lang's former wife
Maggie.[17][26] Cannavale stated that Rudd and McKay convinced him to join the
film during the rewriting process before Marvel approached him, saying, "They
sort of pumped [my] part up a bit...I really went on good faith [taking the
role] because they're so secretive [at Marvel] about the script. I just
trusted them." He also added that the process felt like an indie film instead
of a large-scale blockbuster, and that he was able to improvise frequently
along with the other actors.[26] [Patrick
Wilson](/wiki/Patrick_Wilson_\(American_actor\) "Patrick Wilson \(American
actor\)") was originally cast in the role,[27] before leaving the film because
of scheduling conflicts brought on by the filming delay.[28]

  * [Michael Peña](/wiki/Michael_Pe%C3%B1a "Michael Peña") as [Luis](/wiki/Luis_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Luis \(Marvel Comics\)"):  
Lang's former cellmate and a member of his crew.[29][30] Peña stated that he
modeled Luis' vocal style and positive outlook on life "on a friend of a
friend", saying, "That's just the way he talks and the cadence. He's got this
grin on the entire time and he doesn't care. He's the kind of guy where you're
like 'Hey, what'd you do this weekend?' and he's like 'I went to jail, dawg,'
with a smile on his face. Not a lot of people do that. Not a lot of people
think of life on those terms."[31] Peña signed a contract with Marvel for
three films.[32]

  * [Tip "T.I." Harris](/wiki/T.I. "T.I.") as Dave:[33][34]  
A member of Lang's crew.[29] Harris described Dave as Lang's
"[homeboy](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/homeboy "wikt:homeboy")".[35] Harris
also revealed that he was not permitted to read the entire script, explaining
"You're just handed scenes as the film [went] along, and when you do that,
it's like a blank canvas, 'This is what I'm going to do for this scene,' and
you can remember previous performances and remain consistent with that. The
energy created by the ensemble you have around you, it contributes to the
outlook or the final view of what your character has become, and what he meant
to the story."[36]

  * [Anthony Mackie](/wiki/Anthony_Mackie "Anthony Mackie") as [Sam Wilson / Falcon](/wiki/Falcon_\(comics\) "Falcon \(comics\)"):  
An [Avenger](/wiki/Avengers_\(comics\) "Avengers \(comics\)") who is a former
[pararescueman](/wiki/United_States_Air_Force_Pararescue "United States Air
Force Pararescue") trained by the military in aerial combat using a specially
designed wing pack.[37] On including Falcon, Reed said that it was not done
just to include the character, rather "[i]t served a plot point; a purpose in
our story" and allowed them to enhance Peña's "tip montages", which were
written by production writers Gabriel Ferrari and Andrew Barrer,[38] also
adding Falcon "seemed like the right character — not a marquee character like
[Iron Man](/wiki/Iron_Man "Iron Man") or [Thor](/wiki/Thor_\(Marvel_Comics\)
"Thor \(Marvel Comics\)"), but the right level of hero."[39] Rudd and McKay
decided to include Falcon after watching _Captain America: The Winter
Soldier_.[40]

  * [Wood Harris](/wiki/Wood_Harris "Wood Harris") as Gale:[33][34] A police officer and Paxton's partner.
  * [Judy Greer](/wiki/Judy_Greer "Judy Greer") as Maggie: Lang's estranged former wife.[33][34][41]
  * [David Dastmalchian](/wiki/David_Dastmalchian "David Dastmalchian") as Kurt:[33][34]  
A member of Lang's crew.[29] Dastmalchian, who is American, worked with
actress [Isidora Goreshter](/wiki/Isidora_Goreshter "Isidora Goreshter") to
learn how to speak in his character's Russian accent. On his character,
Dastmalchian said that he "had this idea that Kurt was born and raised in a
town even further out than [Siberia](/wiki/Siberia "Siberia") and he was just
an amazing computer wizard who fell in with the wrong people. But he was
obsessed with two things: _[Saturday Night Fever](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Fever
"Saturday Night Fever")_ and [Elvis Presley](/wiki/Elvis_Presley "Elvis
Presley"), hence the polyester shirts unbuttoned too far and the hair in that
pompadour."[42]

  * [Michael Douglas](/wiki/Michael_Douglas "Michael Douglas") as [Hank Pym](/wiki/Hank_Pym "Hank Pym"):  
A former [S.H.I.E.L.D.](/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D. "S.H.I.E.L.D.") agent,[4]
[entomologist](/wiki/Entomologist "Entomologist"), and physicist who became
the original Ant-Man in 1963 after discovering the [subatomic
particles](/wiki/Subatomic_particle "Subatomic particle") that make the
transformation possible. He later mentors Lang to take over the
role.[7][8][21][43] Douglas compared his decision to join a superhero film to
his role in _[Behind the Candelabra](/wiki/Behind_the_Candelabra "Behind the
Candelabra")_ saying, "Sometimes—like [when] they didn't see you for
[Liberace](/wiki/Liberace "Liberace")—you've got to shake them up a little bit
and have some fun."[44] Describing Pym, Douglas said, "He's sort of a Northern
California, formal guy. He's lost control of his company. He lives in sort of
a time warp. He was always a bit of a tinkerer. He's got a lab, plus a lot of
other stuff, in his basement that we find out about. He's certainly bitter
about what happened with his company and deeply scared of what the future
might hold—because he himself, after having gotten small so many times, it's
difficult. He looks and tries to find a guy that he can work with and has the
right characteristics, which is [Scott]."[17] Douglas indicated that he would
not be wearing the Ant-Man suit.[45]

Additionally, [John Slattery](/wiki/John_Slattery "John Slattery") and [Hayley
Atwell](/wiki/Hayley_Atwell "Hayley Atwell") reprise their roles as [Howard
Stark](/wiki/Howard_Stark "Howard Stark") and [Peggy
Carter](/wiki/Peggy_Carter "Peggy Carter"), respectively, from previous MCU
media.[46][47] Slattery stated that his involvement in _Ant-Man_ was "not that
much more" than his participation in _Iron Man 2_ ,[48] while Atwell described
her appearance as being "more of a cameo".[47] [Abby Ryder
Fortson](/wiki/Abby_Ryder_Fortson "Abby Ryder Fortson") portrays
[Cassie](/wiki/Cassandra_Lang "Cassandra Lang"), the daughter of Lang and
Maggie;[12][18][49] [Gregg Turkington](/wiki/Gregg_Turkington "Gregg
Turkington") appears as Dale, the manager of a [Baskin-Robbins](/wiki/Baskin-
Robbins "Baskin-Robbins") store;[34][50][51] and [Martin
Donovan](/wiki/Martin_Donovan "Martin Donovan") plays [Mitchell
Carson](/wiki/Mitchell_Carson "Mitchell Carson"), a former member of
S.H.I.E.L.D. who works for [Hydra](/wiki/Hydra_\(comics\) "Hydra \(comics\)")
and looks to purchase the Yellowjacket technology.[52][53] YouTuber [Anna
Akana](/wiki/Anna_Akana "Anna Akana") portrays a writer in Luis' story at the
end of the film.[54] [Garrett Morris](/wiki/Garrett_Morris "Garrett Morris"),
who portrayed Ant-Man in a _[Saturday Night Live](/wiki/Saturday_Night_Live
"Saturday Night Live")_ sketch, appears as a taxi driver.[55] Ant-Man co-
creator [Stan Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee") makes a cameo appearance in the
film as a bartender.[56][57] [Chris Evans](/wiki/Chris_Evans_\(actor\) "Chris
Evans \(actor\)") and [Sebastian Stan](/wiki/Sebastian_Stan "Sebastian Stan")
make uncredited appearances during the post-credits scene as [Steve Rogers /
Captain America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America") and [Bucky Barnes /
Winter Soldier](/wiki/Bucky_Barnes "Bucky Barnes"), respectively.[58] [Hayley
Lovitt](/wiki/Hayley_Lovitt "Hayley Lovitt") makes a nonspeaking cameo as
[Janet van Dyne / Wasp](/wiki/Wasp_\(comics\) "Wasp \(comics\)").[59] [Tom
Kenny](/wiki/Tom_Kenny "Tom Kenny") provides the voice of a toy rabbit that
Scott gives to Cassie.[60]

## Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Production")]

### Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-
Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=4 "Edit section: Development")]

Development of an [Ant-Man](/wiki/Ant-Man "Ant-Man") film began as early as
the late 1980s, when Ant-Man co-creator [Stan Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee")
pitched the idea to [New World Pictures](/wiki/New_World_Pictures "New World
Pictures"), [Marvel Comics](/wiki/Marvel_Comics "Marvel Comics")' parent
company at the time. However, [Walt Disney
Pictures](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Pictures "Walt Disney Pictures") was developing a
film based on a similar concept, _[Honey, I Shrunk the
Kids](/wiki/Honey,_I_Shrunk_the_Kids "Honey, I Shrunk the Kids")_ , and
although _Ant-Man_ went into development, nothing came to fruition.[61]

In 2000, [Howard Stern](/wiki/Howard_Stern "Howard Stern") met with Marvel in
an attempt to purchase the film rights to Ant-Man.[62] In May of that year,
[Artisan Entertainment](/wiki/Artisan_Entertainment "Artisan Entertainment")
announced a deal with Marvel to coproduce, finance, and distribute a film
based on Ant-Man.[63] In 2003, [Edgar Wright](/wiki/Edgar_Wright "Edgar
Wright") and his writing partner [Joe Cornish](/wiki/Joe_Cornish "Joe
Cornish") wrote a treatment for Artisan, with Wright explaining that it
revolved around [Scott Lang](/wiki/Scott_Lang "Scott Lang") as a burglar "so
he could have gone slightly in the [Elmore Leonard](/wiki/Elmore_Leonard
"Elmore Leonard") route", though Artisan wanted the film to be "like a family
thing". However, Wright believed that the treatment was never sent to
Marvel.[64] A year later, the duo pitched the film to [Marvel
Studios](/wiki/Marvel_Studios "Marvel Studios")' then head of production,
[Kevin Feige](/wiki/Kevin_Feige "Kevin Feige").[10] In April 2006, Marvel
Studios hired Wright to direct and co-write _Ant-Man_ with Cornish as part of
the company's first slate of independently produced films. Wright would also
co-produce the film with his [Big Talk Productions](/wiki/Big_Talk_Productions
"Big Talk Productions") partner [Nira Park](/wiki/Nira_Park "Nira Park").[65]

"The thing I like about Ant-Man is that it's not like a secret power, there's
no supernatural element or it's not a genetic thing. There's no gamma rays.
It's just like the suit and the gas, so in that sense, it really appealed to
me in terms that we could do something high-concept, really visual, cross-
genre, sort of an action and special effects bonanza, but funny as well."

—Screenwriter Edgar Wright[66]

At the 2006 [San Diego Comic-Con International](/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-
Con_International "San Diego Comic-Con International"), Wright said he was
intrigued by the story's high concept and character. Wright also stressed that
the film would not be a [spoof](/wiki/Spoof_film "Spoof film") but an action-
adventure with some comedic elements and would incorporate both the [Hank
Pym](/wiki/Hank_Pym "Hank Pym") and Scott Lang incarnations of the
character.[67] Wright said that he was looking to "do a prologue where you see
Pym as Ant-Man in action in the 60s, in sort of _[Tales to
Astonish](/wiki/Tales_to_Astonish "Tales to Astonish")_ mode basically, and
then the contemporary, sort of flash-forward, is Scott Lang's story, and how
he comes to acquire the suit, how he crosses paths with Hank Pym, and then, in
an interesting sort of Machiavellian way, teams up with him."[66] The next
February, Wright said that the project was in "a holding pattern" while the
script was being revised,[68] and that he had been doing research for the film
by studying [nanotechnology](/wiki/Nanotechnology "Nanotechnology").[69] In
March 2008, Wright said that the first draft of the script had been completed
and he was working on the second.[70]

[Stan Lee](/wiki/Stan_Lee "Stan Lee") [tweeted](/wiki/Twitter "Twitter") in
February 2010 that Marvel was prepping the film and that he met with Wright
for lunch to discuss the character.[71] Wright noted that there was no
timetable for the film because Marvel did not consider the character to be one
of their bigger, tentpole properties, so "It's more like me and Kevin Feige
saying...'Let's make a good script that works, that's all about a great genre
film, and that isn't necessarily relying on anything else'".[72] At the 2010
San Diego Comic-Con International, Wright said that Ant-Man would not fit in
the chronology of _[The Avengers](/wiki/The_Avengers_\(2012_film\) "The
Avengers \(2012 film\)")_ due to the origin story he had written not working
in the MCU.[73] In January 2011, Wright stated that he had resumed writing the
script for the film following the conclusion of the international promotion
for _[Scott Pilgrim vs. the World](/wiki/Scott_Pilgrim_vs._the_World "Scott
Pilgrim vs. the World")_ ,[74] and by April he and Cornish delivered the
second draft of _Ant-Man_ to Marvel.[75] At the 2011 San Diego Comic-Con
International, Wright revealed a third draft had been handed in.[76]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d7/San_Diego_Comic-
Con_2012_-_Ant-Man_announcement.jpg/220px-San_Diego_Comic-Con_2012_-_Ant-
Man_announcement.jpg)](/wiki/File:San_Diego_Comic-Con_2012_-_Ant-
Man_announcement.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:San_Diego_Comic-Con_2012_-_Ant-Man_announcement.jpg "Enlarge")

(L-R) moderator Geoff Boucher, producer [Kevin Feige](/wiki/Kevin_Feige "Kevin
Feige") and Wright at the 2012 [San Diego Comic-Con
International](/wiki/San_Diego_Comic-Con_International "San Diego Comic-Con
International")

In May 2012, Feige said that the project was "as close as it's ever been"
while Wright teased the film by tweeting a pictogram of Ant-Man.[77] In June,
Wright spent just under a week shooting footage for a reel that would be used
to test out the potential look and tone of his movie, as well as to decide how
convincing Ant-Man's powers look on screen.[78] The test footage was screened
to audiences during the Marvel Studios panel at the 2012 San Diego Comic-Con
International, with Wright confirming that _Ant-Man_ would be happening.[79]
Germain Lussier of [/Film](/wiki//Film "/Film") felt the footage worked and
was "awesome", as "it had a totally different vibe from the other Marvel
films. It was much more like something you'd recognize from _[Hot
Fuzz](/wiki/Hot_Fuzz "Hot Fuzz")_."[80] Lussier, along with Katy Rich of
CinemaBlend, also enjoyed the costume design choice.[80][81] That October,
Disney scheduled the film for release on November 6, 2015.[82]

Feige stated in January 2013 that _Ant-Man_ would be part of Phase Three of
the [Marvel Cinematic Universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel
Cinematic Universe"),[83] and indicated in May that the screenplay needed to
be modified in order to fit into the universe, as the project had been in
development before the first _[Iron Man](/wiki/Iron_Man_\(2008_film\) "Iron
Man \(2008 film\)")_ film. Feige also stated that shooting was slated to begin
sometime in 2014,[84] and that casting would begin towards the end of
2013.[85] In July 2013, Wright said that he and Cornish had completed the
script for the film and that Marvel allowed him to delay its production so
that he could complete _[The World's End](/wiki/The_World%27s_End_\(film\)
"The World's End \(film\)")_,[86] as that film's producer [Eric
Fellner](/wiki/Eric_Fellner "Eric Fellner") was diagnosed with cancer.[87]

In August 2013, after [Joss Whedon](/wiki/Joss_Whedon "Joss Whedon"), director
of _[Avengers: Age of Ultron](/wiki/Avengers:_Age_of_Ultron "Avengers: Age of
Ultron")_ , announced that Hank Pym would not be [Ultron](/wiki/Ultron
"Ultron")'s creator, Wright said Ultron was never a part of the story of _Ant-
Man_ ,[88] explaining that "just to sort of set up what Ant-Man does is enough
for one movie".[89] Wright described _Ant-Man_ as a [stand-alone](/wiki/Stand-
alone_sequel "Stand-alone sequel") film but said it would fit into the larger
continuity of the Marvel Cinematic Universe, explaining, "I like to make it
standalone because I think the premise of it needs time. I want to put the
crazy premise of it into a real world, which is why I think _Iron Man_ really
works because it's a relatively simple universe; it's relatable. I definitely
want to go into finding a streamlined format where you use the origin format
to introduce the main character and further adventures can bring other people
into it."[90] Wright also stated that pre-production for _Ant-Man_ would begin
in October and filming would begin in 2014.[91] The next month, Disney moved
the film's release date up to July 31, 2015.[92]

### Pre-production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-
Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=5 "Edit section: Pre-production")]

In October 2013, Wright revealed that he was in Los Angeles to work on _Ant-
Man_ by tweeting a photograph from the production of the June 2012 test
reel.[93] [Joseph Gordon-Levitt](/wiki/Joseph_Gordon-Levitt "Joseph Gordon-
Levitt") and [Paul Rudd](/wiki/Paul_Rudd "Paul Rudd") were soon being
considered for the lead role,[94] though Gordon-Levitt dismissed his
consideration as a rumor.[95] Feige stated that _Ant-Man_ would be a "[heist
movie](/wiki/Heist_film "Heist film")", and that a casting announcement for
Hank Pym would come before the end of 2013.[96] The next month, Feige stated
that [Eric O'Grady](/wiki/Eric_O%27Grady "Eric O'Grady")'s Ant-Man would not
be featured in the film,[97] while Rudd became the front-runner to play Hank
Pym, and casting for the character's girlfriend had begun.[98] Around that
time, the filmmakers' intentions to shoot in the United Kingdom were dashed
because of a lack of studio space, which Wright believed was due to the plan
by [Pinewood Shepperton](/wiki/The_Pinewood_Studios_Group "The Pinewood
Studios Group") to add fifteen studios to their facility, which was rejected
in part by the local council in May 2013 because the project was eyeing
protected land.[99][100] By the end of the month, the film was scheduled to be
shot in the U.S. instead.[101]

In December 2013, Wright, a fan of the comic book since childhood—owning
copies of _Tales to Astonish_ #27 featuring "The Man in the Ant-Hill"
storyline and _[Marvel Premiere](/wiki/Marvel_Premiere "Marvel Premiere")_ #47
featuring the first appearance of Scott Lang—[102] stated that the difference
between _Ant-Man_ and other films featuring size-changing is "other shrinking
movies are usually about somebody trapped small. This is different in that he
can actually change size and he can do that at will, so it becomes more of a
power than an impediment."[103] Wright also talked about the challenge of
directing a superhero film, saying, "_Shaun_ and _Hot Fuzz_ and _World 's End_
are all R-rated films. I like the challenge of making a PG-13 film. Because
you've got to entertain in a different way. You don't have the same
tools."[104] By December 19, Rudd was in negotiations to star in the
film,[105][106] and Marvel announced that he had been cast as Ant-Man the next
day.[107]

In January 2014, Wright posted a screenshot on his blog from the _[Avengers:
Earth's Mightiest Heroes](/wiki/Avengers:_Earth%27s_Mightiest_Heroes
"Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes")_ episode "[To Steal an Ant-
Man](/wiki/List_of_The_Avengers:_Earth%27s_Mightiest_Heroes_episodes#To_Steal_an_Ant-
Man "List of The Avengers: Earth's Mightiest Heroes episodes")", which
features Hank Pym and introduces the Scott Lang character, with the caption
"homework".[108][109] [Michael Douglas](/wiki/Michael_Douglas "Michael
Douglas") was subsequently cast as Pym, with Rudd confirmed to play Lang.[7]
[Michael Peña](/wiki/Michael_Pe%C3%B1a "Michael Peña") was offered an
unspecified role in the film,[110] and filming was scheduled to take place at
[Pinewood Atlanta](/wiki/Pinewood_Studios#Pinewood_Atlanta "Pinewood Studios")
in [Fayette County, Georgia](/wiki/Fayette_County,_Georgia "Fayette County,
Georgia"),[111] while Disney changed the release date once again, moving the
film up to July 17, 2015.[112] The next month, [Evangeline
Lilly](/wiki/Evangeline_Lilly "Evangeline Lilly") entered early talks to
portray the female lead,[13] and Wright announced on his blog that [Bill
Pope](/wiki/Bill_Pope "Bill Pope"), who he worked with on _Scott Pilgrim vs.
the World_ and _The World 's End_, would be his [director of
photography](/wiki/Cinematographer "Cinematographer").[113] By March, Wright
and Cornish turned in a fifth draft of the script, amid alleged disputes on
the direction the script was taking. As well, Wright and Cornish wrote a scene
intended for the post-credits of _Avengers: Age of Ultron_ that would have
acted as a prelude to the film.[114] [Corey Stoll](/wiki/Corey_Stoll "Corey
Stoll") entered negotiations for an undisclosed role in the film,[22] and by
April, [Patrick Wilson](/wiki/Patrick_Wilson_\(American_actor\) "Patrick
Wilson \(American actor\)") and [Matt Gerald](/wiki/Matt_Gerald "Matt Gerald")
were cast in undisclosed roles.[115][116]

"Ant-Man is interesting because he was one of the original
[Avengers](/wiki/Avengers_\(comics\) "Avengers \(comics\)"), which I think
people forget about. So, I like that idea in the [movie
universe](/wiki/Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Marvel Cinematic Universe")... I
also like that it's this sort of passing of the torch. There's sort of a weird
mentor / pupil thing happening between Michael Douglas' character Hank Pym and
Scott Lang, which Paul Rudd plays. Hank Pym used to be old Ant-Man and he is
trying to find someone to be the new Ant-Man. I like that. I think that's sort
of a classic Marvel Comics thing and something that we really haven't seen in
that universe."

—[Peyton Reed](/wiki/Peyton_Reed "Peyton Reed"), director of _Ant-Man_[117]

On May 23, 2014, Marvel and Wright jointly announced that Wright was leaving
the project due to "differences in their vision of the film", and that the
studio was closing in on a new director.[118] On the split, Wright said, "I
wanted to make a Marvel movie but I don’t think they really wanted to make an
Edgar Wright movie." He also added that at one point, Marvel wanted to do a
draft of the script without him, which was "a tough thing to move forward" as
Wright has written all of the previous films he directed. Wright continued,
"Suddenly becoming a director-for-hire on it, you’re sort of less emotionally
invested and you start to wonder why you’re there, really."[119] The majority
of Wright's crew also left the project in the wake of his departure.[120][119]
By May 30, [Adam McKay](/wiki/Adam_McKay "Adam McKay") had entered
negotiations to replace Wright,[121] but pulled out of negotiations the next
day.[122] On June 7, Marvel announced that [Peyton Reed](/wiki/Peyton_Reed
"Peyton Reed") would direct the film, with McKay contributing to the film's
script.[5] Other directors that had been under consideration include [Ruben
Fleischer](/wiki/Ruben_Fleischer "Ruben Fleischer"), [Rawson Marshall
Thurber](/wiki/Rawson_Marshall_Thurber "Rawson Marshall Thurber"), [Nicholas
Stoller](/wiki/Nicholas_Stoller "Nicholas Stoller"), [Michael
Dowse](/wiki/Michael_Dowse "Michael Dowse"), and [David Wain](/wiki/David_Wain
"David Wain").[123][124][125][126]

Later in June, Feige stated the film was still intended to be released on the
July 17, 2015 date, with production slated to begin on August 18,
2014.[127][128] Feige elaborated that "much of the movie will still be based
very much on [Wright and Cornish's] draft and the DNA of what Edgar has
created up to this point", with Reed stepping in to direct and McKay reworking
only parts of the script. "[Reed] wanted to be sure that he wasn't just
inheriting something or following someone else's lead. Or wasn't inheriting
something that the evil studio had watered down to be something bad," Feige
continued. "He looked at everything, he talked with us, and he said 'Number
one, I agree with the direction you're going in. And number two, I can add to
it.'"[129]

McKay stated that Rudd helped him rewrite the script, calling Rudd "great with
dialogue", adding "the two of us holed up in hotel rooms on the east and west
coast, and I think it was like six to eight weeks we just ground it out and
did a giant rewrite of the script. I was really proud of what we did, I really
thought we put some amazing stuff in there and built on an already strong
script from Edgar Wright and sort of just enhanced some stuff."[130] Rudd
elaborated, "The idea, the trajectory, the goal, and the blueprint of it all,
is really Edgar and Joe. It's their story. We changed some scenes, we added
new sequences, we changed some characters, we added new characters. If you
took the two scripts and held them up together they'd be very different—but
the idea is all theirs."[131] Reed also offered contributions to the revised
script, as did Lilly and Stoll, who contributed ideas to help flesh out their
respective characters. Lilly's character received a fuller arc and more action
sequences as a result.[17] One of the important things when joining the film
for Reed was emphasizing both Hope and Janet van Dyne more, given the Wasp
being "a crucial part" of the Ant-Man comics.[132] For their efforts, McKay
and Rudd were credited as additional writers of the screenplay, with Wright
and Cornish credited for the screenplay and story.[133] Wright also held an
executive producer credit on the film.[134]

By the end of July, Wilson left the film because of scheduling conflicts
brought on by the filming delay, and characters being played by Gerald and
[Kevin Weisman](/wiki/Kevin_Weisman "Kevin Weisman") were cut in McKay's
revised script.[28] Also, Reed indicated that in addition to Georgia, filming
would take place in San Francisco.[135] The next month, Reed revealed that
[Scott Lang's daughter](/wiki/Cassandra_Lang "Cassandra Lang") would appear in
the film,[136] and Gabriel Ferrari and Andrew Barrer were hired to make
further revisions to the script.[137] [Eric Pearson](/wiki/Eric_Pearson "Eric
Pearson"), a member of Marvel Studios' writing program who had written the
[Marvel One-Shot](/wiki/Marvel_One-Shot "Marvel One-Shot") films, did
uncredited work on the film as well,[138] scripting the strip club scene and
Stan Lee's cameo.[139] After reading the revised script, Evangeline Lilly felt
that the film was "pulled" more into the MCU than Wright's version which "was
much more in the Edgar Wright camp of films." She added that, while Wright's
version was "incredible" and would have been great to film and watch, "it
wouldn't have fit in the Marvel Universe. It would have stuck out like a sore
thumb, no matter how good it was. It just would have taken you away from this
cohesive universe they're trying to create. And therefore it ruins the
suspended disbelief that they've built."[15]

[Arnim Zola](/wiki/Arnim_Zola "Arnim Zola") from _[Captain America: The First
Avenger](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_First_Avenger "Captain America: The First
Avenger")_ and _[Captain America: The Winter
Soldier](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_Winter_Soldier "Captain America: The
Winter Soldier")_ was considered to make an appearance in the film, with
concept art created depicting him in his robot body from the comics.[140]

### Filming[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Filming")]

[Principal photography](/wiki/Principal_photography "Principal photography")
began on August 18, 2014 in San Francisco,[34] under the [working
title](/wiki/Working_title "Working title") _Bigfoot_.[4] Scenes were shot in
the [Tenderloin](/wiki/Tenderloin,_San_Francisco "Tenderloin, San Francisco")
neighborhood and [Buena Vista Park](/wiki/Buena_Vista_Park "Buena Vista
Park").[141] By the end of September 2014, production on _Ant-Man_ moved to
Pinewood Atlanta Studios in Fayette County, Georgia,[142] and [David
Callaham](/wiki/David_Callaham "David Callaham") completed a rewrite of the
film.[143] Filming also took place at the State Archives building in [Downtown
Atlanta](/wiki/Downtown_Atlanta "Downtown Atlanta"),[144] to double as Pym
Technologies, which is located on [Treasure Island, San
Francisco](/wiki/Treasure_Island,_San_Francisco "Treasure Island, San
Francisco") in the film.[145] In October 2014, [Martin
Donovan](/wiki/Martin_Donovan "Martin Donovan") was added to the cast,[52] and
Feige revealed that _Ant-Man_ would no longer start Phase Three of the Marvel
Cinematic Universe and would instead be the final film of Phase Two.[146] When
told by [/Film](/wiki//Film "/Film")'s Germain Lussier that this placement
between _Avengers: Age of Ultron_ and _[Captain America: Civil
War](/wiki/Captain_America:_Civil_War "Captain America: Civil War")_ made the
film feel like an afterthought, Feige replied,

> It's not [an after thought]. The truth is the phases mean a lot to me and
> some people but..._Civil War_ is the start of Phase Three. It just is. And
> _Ant-Man_ is a different kind of culmination of Phase Two because it very
> much is in the MCU. You meet new characters and you learn about Hank Pym and
> his lineage with the MCU over the years. But at the same time, it also picks
> up the thread of _Age of Ultron_ in terms of heroes—major heroes,
> Avengers—coming from unexpected places... And in that way it connects a lot.
> Also, Hank Pym's attitude towards Avengers, towards
> [S.H.I.E.L.D.](/wiki/S.H.I.E.L.D. "S.H.I.E.L.D."), and kind of the cinematic
> universe in general, is much more informed after the events of _Age of
> Ultron_ , and in a certain way, before the events of _Civil War_.[147]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Peyton_Reed_%28cropped%29.jpg/170px-
Peyton_Reed_%28cropped%29.jpg)](/wiki/File:Peyton_Reed_\(cropped\).jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Peyton_Reed_\(cropped\).jpg "Enlarge")

Reed at the world premiere of _Ant-Man_ in Hollywood

Feige later expanded on this by saying, "[W]e put _Ant-Man_ at the end of
Phase Two as opposed to the beginning of Phase Three, because it sets up a lot
of the things you're going to see heading into Phase Three, one of which is
this mind-bending, reality-altering landscape [in _[Doctor
Strange](/wiki/Doctor_Strange_\(2016_film\) "Doctor Strange \(2016
film\)")_]."[40] On December 5, 2014, Reed announced on social media that
principal photography on _Ant-Man_ had been completed.[148]

For the film, cinematographer [Russell Carpenter](/wiki/Russell_Carpenter
"Russell Carpenter") used a 1.85 [aspect ratio](/wiki/Aspect_ratio "Aspect
ratio") shot with [Arri Alexa XT](/wiki/Arri_Alexa#Alexa_XT "Arri Alexa") and
[M](/wiki/Arri_Alexa#Alexa_M "Arri Alexa") cameras, using the M for fight
sequences and helicopter filming. Camera operator Peter Rosenfeld said,
"Russell and Peyton's decision to shoot in 1.85 was a good call, since at 2.35
there's insufficient height in frame to appreciate the vertical aspects of
[Ant-Man] going from standing full-size to falling through a crack in the
floor." Carpenter and [Technicolor](/wiki/Technicolor "Technicolor") also
devised a [lookup table](/wiki/Lookup_table "Lookup table") (LUT) to darken
the color palette. Carpenter said, "For a lot of recent comedies I've kept my
LUTs kind of '[Kodak](/wiki/Kodak "Kodak")' – saturated and upbeat. But this
show needed something different that affected skin tones and the Ant-Man suit,
which dates back to the 1980s, so it looks a little run-down. What I loved
about this LUT was how it allowed the costume to retain the color but took it
from fire-engine red to something a little more weathered."[149]

The filmmakers made extensive use of [macro
photography](/wiki/Macro_photography "Macro photography"). Production designer
Shepherd Frankel said, "It's more visually interesting to depict things from
Ant-Man's point of view instead of seeing him from a normal perspective. But
we wanted a realistic realization, not _Honey, I Shrunk the Kids_ with its
oversized set pieces."[149] Rebecca Baehler served as the director of macro
photography, taking cues from Carpenter.[150] Carpenter said vibration became
"a tremendous problem" when moving the camera during the macro photography
because "one inch off the ground is like fifteen feet in the air. From an
ant's perspective, you move four inches, to a human perspective, that's a
football field!" The solution required the filmmakers to search for a creative
solution, so they turned to Baehler, who had a background in commercial
"tabletop" photography. In order to add Rudd's performance as Ant-Man when in
the macro world, a Centroid facial capture set up was used, with a five-camera
array of Alexas surrounding Rudd. Rosenfeld explained, "One camera was set up
vertically while the others were horizontal with overlapping image areas, all
set to record at 48 frames per second. This maximized resolution and provided
3D modeling [of] Paul's performance." Reed would then call out story moments
with Rudd performing "facial expressions that would later be composited on a
[CG](/wiki/Computer_graphics "Computer graphics") Ant-Man."[149]

### Post-production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-
Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=7 "Edit section: Post-production")]

Following the completion of principal photography, Marvel released an updated
synopsis revealing that [Jordi Mollà](/wiki/Jordi_Moll%C3%A0 "Jordi Mollà")
was included in the cast and the names of several supporting characters.[33]
However, Mollà subsequently did not appear in the theatrical release of the
film. Reed explained that the film's original opening, which was filmed and
cut in the editing process, featured a standalone sequence similar to the
opening of a [James Bond film](/wiki/James_Bond_in_film "James Bond in film"),
where an unseen Pym was attempting to retrieve some microfilm from Mollà's
character, Castillo, a Panama army general. Reed stated the scene was going to
show Ant-Man's powers, without seeing him, almost "like an Invisible Man
sequence, and it's really, really cool. It started to feel tonally
disconnected from the movie we were making and story-wise, and it also kind of
like, it set a standalone adventure, but it didn’t just connect to the rest of
our story...It felt like vestige of those earlier drafts [by Wright and
Cornish], which as a standalone thing was really cool."[151] Dan Lebental and
Colby Parker, Jr. served as [film editors](/wiki/Film_editing "Film
editing").[34] In March 2015, [Hayley Atwell](/wiki/Hayley_Atwell "Hayley
Atwell") confirmed that she would reprise her role as [Peggy
Carter](/wiki/Peggy_Carter "Peggy Carter") in the film.[47] In April 2015,
Reed stated that the film was not completed yet and would be undergoing "a
little bit of additional" filming.[152]

In June 2015, Feige confirmed that the character of Janet van Dyne would be
seen, though the film would not address Pym and van Dyne's infamous domestic
abuse storyline in the comics, saying, "We hint at a temper in a way that
people who know the stories might go, 'Oh, perhaps that's a bit of [Hank's]
character,' but not in a way that would ever indicate [he beat his
wife]."[153] Also in the month, Reed confirmed there would be a post-credit
sequence "that may tie into the other films."[154] Feige revealed the post-
credit sequence was footage shot by [Anthony and Joe
Russo](/wiki/Russo_brothers "Russo brothers") for _[Captain America: Civil
War](/wiki/Captain_America:_Civil_War "Captain America: Civil War")_ , saying
the clip would be seen in that film, though it may be "different
takes...different angles."[155][156] On June 25, 2015, Reed announced on
social media that production of _Ant-Man_ was officially complete.[157] In
early July 2015, an international teaser trailer revealed that [Anthony
Mackie](/wiki/Anthony_Mackie "Anthony Mackie") would appear in the film as
[Sam Wilson / Falcon](/wiki/Falcon_\(comics\) "Falcon \(comics\)").[37] Mackie
appears in the post-credit sequence as well, along with [Chris
Evans](/wiki/Chris_Evans_\(actor\) "Chris Evans \(actor\)") and [Sebastian
Stan](/wiki/Sebastian_Stan "Sebastian Stan") as [Steve Rogers / Captain
America](/wiki/Captain_America "Captain America") and [Bucky Barnes / Winter
Soldier](/wiki/Bucky_Barnes "Bucky Barnes"), respectively.[58] Stan stated the
scene that was used for the post-credit sequence was shot in May 2015, and
would appear in the middle of _Civil War_.[158] Also in the month, Reed
revealed that the quantum realm in the film was the MCU's version of the
[microverse](/wiki/Microverse "Microverse"),[38] which could not be called
that due to legal reasons. The alternate name was suggested by consultant
Spiros Michalakis, a quantum physicist and staff researcher at the [California
Institute of Technology](/wiki/California_Institute_of_Technology "California
Institute of Technology"), to "inject elements of modern physics into the
script".[159] Reed also said that the end of the film originally had a
sequence where Ant-Man went after Carson to retrieve the stolen vial of Cross'
particles, "... But then for a couple reasons, it felt like maybe we should
leave those particles out there."[160] For the title sequences, Marvel again
went with design firm Sarofsky, who had done the credits for both _Captain
America: The Winter Soldier_ and _[Guardians of the
Galaxy](/wiki/Guardians_of_the_Galaxy_\(film\) "Guardians of the Galaxy
\(film\)")_ , with the credits "intricately connected to the film's overall
narrative."[161]

#### Visual effects[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-
Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=8 "Edit section: Visual effects")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/e/e6/Corey_Stoll_as_Yellowjacket.jpg/220px-
Corey_Stoll_as_Yellowjacket.jpg)](/wiki/File:Corey_Stoll_as_Yellowjacket.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Corey_Stoll_as_Yellowjacket.jpg "Enlarge")

For Yellowjacket sequences, Stoll wore a [motion capture](/wiki/Motion_capture
"Motion capture") suit while on set (top), which was replaced by an entirely
digital creation built by Double Negative (bottom).[150]

Visual effects for the film were provided by [Industrial Light &
Magic](/wiki/Industrial_Light_%26_Magic "Industrial Light & Magic") (ILM),
Lola VFX, [Double Negative](/wiki/Double_Negative_\(VFX\) "Double Negative
\(VFX\)"), [Luma Pictures](/wiki/Luma_Pictures "Luma Pictures"), and [Method
Studios](/wiki/Method_Studios "Method Studios"), with
[previsualization](/wiki/Previsualization "Previsualization") by The Third
Floor.[17][150][162] Double Negative handled the scenes featuring shrunken
characters, incorporating the macro photography and [motion
capture](/wiki/Motion_capture "Motion capture") performances shot in principal
photography with digital models of the characters. Double Negative also worked
on Ant-Man's shrinking effect, in coordination with ILM to be used by all
vendors, which showed the outline of his body – an element from the comics.
Visual effects supervisor Alex Wuttke said, "It's like a little time echo. As
Ant-Man shrinks in almost a stop motion way he would leave behind outlines of
the poses he'd been in as he shrinks down... We'd have two CG cameras
rendering the action from different points along the timeline with slightly
different framings. One would be the main shot camera, the other would be a
utility camera that would provide renders of static poses of Ant-Man at
different points along the timeline."[150]

For the flashbacks in 1989, Douglas and Donovan appeared [de-aged](/wiki/De-
aging_in_film "De-aging in film") via CGI, alongside Atwell as Carter (aged in
makeup and with CGI) and [John Slattery](/wiki/John_Slattery "John Slattery")
as [Howard Stark](/wiki/Howard_Stark "Howard Stark").[4][50][150][153] To de-
age Douglas, Lola VFX used a similar process and technology that was used to
make Steve Rogers skinny in _[Captain America: The First
Avenger](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_First_Avenger "Captain America: The First
Avenger")_ and Carter older in _[Captain America: The Winter
Soldier](/wiki/Captain_America:_The_Winter_Soldier "Captain America: The
Winter Soldier")_ as well as footage of Douglas' other films from the late
1980s as reference.[40][162] [Dax Griffin](/wiki/Dax_Griffin "Dax Griffin")
served as Douglas' [body double](/wiki/Body_double "Body double") and an
additional reference for Lola, because of his "striking resemblance of Michael
when he was about 40".[162][163] For Donovan, he only needed to be de-aged
about a decade, so no double was used. The work on him focused on his eyes,
neck, and chin. Atwell wore a wig on set, along with a fine layer of latex
makeup to give the skin a more leathery look, with Lola transposing the facial
features of an elderly actress onto her face.[150]

Method and Luma both worked on creating the various ants seen in the film,
with Method creating the several species of ants, to share among the vendors.
Luma also handled many of the scenes at Pym Technologies when Ant-Man attempts
to acquire the Yellowjacket. ILM worked on the Falcon fight sequence, having
done Falcon visual effects in _The Winter Soldier_. Using practical suit
pieces built by [Legacy Effects](/wiki/Legacy_Effects "Legacy Effects"), ILM
mixed live-action shots with digital take-overs and fully digital shots to
create the sequence. ILM also handled the sequences in the quantum realm,
providing an array of microscopic and largely psychedelic imagery for the
subatomic shrinking, taking advantage of procedural fractal rendering
techniques the studio had utilized on _[Lucy](/wiki/Lucy_\(2014_film\) "Lucy
\(2014 film\)")_.[150]

## Music[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Music")]

Main article: [Ant-Man (soundtrack)](/wiki/Ant-Man_\(soundtrack\) "Ant-Man
\(soundtrack\)")

In February 2014, Wright tweeted that [Steven
Price](/wiki/Steven_Price_\(composer\) "Steven Price \(composer\)") would
[score](/wiki/Film_score "Film score") the film.[113] However, Price left soon
after Wright's departure from the project in May 2014.[120] In January 2015,
[Christophe Beck](/wiki/Christophe_Beck "Christophe Beck"), who worked with
Reed on _[Bring It On](/wiki/Bring_It_On_\(film\) "Bring It On \(film\)")_ ,
was hired to replace Price.[164] Describing the film's score, Beck said, "For
_Ant-Man_ , I wanted to write a score in the grand symphonic tradition of my
favorite superhero movies, with a sweeping scope and a big, catchy main theme.
What makes this score stand out among other Marvel movies, though, is a sneaky
sense of fun since it is, after all, not only a superhero movie, but also a
heist comedy."[165] [Hollywood Records](/wiki/Hollywood_Records "Hollywood
Records") released the soundtrack digitally on July 17, 2015, and had a
physical release on August 7.[166]

## Release[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Release")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/Paul_Rudd_%28cropped%29_2.jpg/170px-
Paul_Rudd_%28cropped%29_2.jpg)](/wiki/File:Paul_Rudd_\(cropped\)_2.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Paul_Rudd_\(cropped\)_2.jpg "Enlarge")

Rudd at the world premiere of _Ant-Man_ in Hollywood

_Ant-Man_ premiered at the [Dolby Theatre](/wiki/Dolby_Theatre "Dolby
Theatre") in Hollywood on June 29, 2015,[167] and opened the 2015 [Fantasia
International Film Festival](/wiki/Fantasia_International_Film_Festival
"Fantasia International Film Festival") on July 14, 2015, along with _[Miss
Hokusai](/wiki/Miss_Hokusai "Miss Hokusai")_.[168] The film was released in
France on July 14,[169] and was released in North America on July 17,[112] in
[3D](/wiki/3D_film "3D film") and [IMAX 3D](/wiki/IMAX_3D "IMAX
3D").[170][171] The film was released in the United States in 3,800 theaters,
with the breakdown of 3,100 3D screens, 361 IMAX screens, 388 [large
format](/wiki/Large_format_\(photography\) "Large format \(photography\)")
screens and 133 [D-Box](/wiki/D-Box_Technologies "D-Box Technologies")
screens.[169] _Ant-Man_ had originally been scheduled for release on November
6, 2015.[82] In September 2013, the release was moved to July 31, 2015,[92]
before changing for a final time to July 17, 2015 in January 2014.[112] An
unfinished version of the film was screened on June 24, 2015, at
[CineEurope](/wiki/CineEurope "CineEurope").[172]

### Marketing[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-
Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=11 "Edit section: Marketing")]

In March 2014, [ABC](/wiki/American_Broadcasting_Company "American
Broadcasting Company") aired a one-hour [television
special](/wiki/Television_special "Television special"), _Marvel Studios:
Assembling a Universe_ , which included a sneak peek of _Ant-Man_.[173][174]
In July 2014, Reed, Rudd, Douglas, Lilly, and Stoll appeared at Marvel
Studios' panel at the 2014 San Diego Comic-Con International to help promote
the film and screen a visual effects test featuring Rudd and Douglas.[21] In
October 2014, Marvel Comics' Editor-in-Chief [Axel Alonso](/wiki/Axel_Alonso
"Axel Alonso") stated there are comic tie-in plans for the film.[175] In
November 2014, ABC aired another one-hour television special titled, _[Marvel
75 Years: From Pulp to Pop!](/wiki/Marvel_75_Years:_From_Pulp_to_Pop! "Marvel
75 Years: From Pulp to Pop!")_ , which featured behind the scenes footage of
_Ant-Man_.[176] Marvel Comics' February 2015 solicitations released in
December 2014, revealed a two-issue comic tie-in, _Marvel 's Ant-Man Prelude_,
following Hank Pym as Ant-Man on a mission during the Cold War.[177] A second
comic tie-in, _Marvel 's Ant-Man—Scott Lang: Small Time_, was released
digitally on March 3, 2015. It explains Lang's circumstances at the beginning
of the film.[178]

In January 2015, Disney officially began the film's marketing campaign by
releasing a miniature "ant-sized" teaser trailer, a full-sized version of the
same teaser trailer, a poster, a cover on _[Entertainment
Weekly](/wiki/Entertainment_Weekly "Entertainment Weekly")_ , and a full-
length trailer during the premiere of the television series _[Agent
Carter](/wiki/Agent_Carter_\(TV_series\) "Agent Carter \(TV series\)")_. Scott
Mendelson of _[Forbes](/wiki/Forbes "Forbes")_ , said, "It was darn-clever for
Disney to put out a miniature 'can't see anything without a microscope'
version of the now-standard trailer for the trailer. I sighed just a little
when they 'gave in' and released a human-sized version, realizing that Disney
had just released what amounted to a teaser to a teaser to a trailer... But
nonetheless, credit where credit is due, Disney was able to turn a single
theatrical trailer into three separate news drops in about five days."
Mendelson went on to say that "the peppy, witty trailer above is a general
audience sell. Marvel knows the geeks will come if only to throw stones, but
it's the mainstream audience that needs to be sold. So far, so good."[179]
However, Graeme McMillan of _[The Hollywood
Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood Reporter")_ criticized
the trailer for its placement during the broadcast premiere of _Agent Carter_
, its tone, its soundtrack, and for being thematically similar to other
trailers from Marvel Studios. McMillan concluded, "The _Ant-Man_ trailer isn't
bad, per se; it is, however, impressively underwhelming, which almost seems
worse. Thanks to the last-minute exit of original writer-director Edgar Wright
and the subsequent struggle to find a replacement, _Ant-Man_ has become the
movie that people are expecting to be Marvel's first failure, in critical if
not financial terms, at least; this trailer, which fails to convince and gets
by on goodwill for those involved and the Marvel brand as much as anything
else, doesn't do enough — or anything, really — to persuade audiences that
that's not the case."[180] The trailer generated 29 million views worldwide in
three days, the third-largest viewership for a Marvel Studios film, behind
trailers for _[Iron Man 3](/wiki/Iron_Man_3 "Iron Man 3")_ and _Avengers: Age
of Ultron_.[181]

In April 2015, Marvel debuted a second trailer for _Ant-Man_. Mendelson said
it was "frankly the _Ant-Man_ trailer that we've been waiting for. It's not
just funny and exciting, it's an 'Ah ha!' moment when we realize just what
exactly an _Ant-Man_ movie has to offer."[182] Also in April, miniature
[billboards](/wiki/Billboard "Billboard") promoting _Ant-Man_ with battery-
powered [LED](/wiki/Light-emitting_diode "Light-emitting diode") lights began
appearing in [Melbourne](/wiki/Melbourne "Melbourne"),
[Brisbane](/wiki/Brisbane "Brisbane") and other areas around
[Queensland](/wiki/Queensland "Queensland"), Australia as part of a [street
marketing](/wiki/Street_marketing "Street marketing") campaign for the
film.[183] The next month, Marvel, in partnership with [Dolby
Laboratories](/wiki/Dolby_Laboratories "Dolby Laboratories"),
[Visa](/wiki/Visa_Inc. "Visa Inc."), and [Raspberry Pi](/wiki/Raspberry_Pi
"Raspberry Pi"), announced the "Ant-Man Micro-Tech Challenge", aimed at
females aged 14 through 18, to create [DIY](/wiki/Do_it_yourself "Do it
yourself") projects involving micro technology and readily accessible and
found materials. Winners teamed with [STEM](/wiki/STEM_fields "STEM fields")
(Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics education) programs in
their areas to lead teams in recreating their projects.[184] In June, Marvel
released posters featuring Ant-Man juxtaposed with [Iron Man's
armor](/wiki/Iron_Man%27s_armor_in_other_media#Live_action "Iron Man's armor
in other media"), [Captain America's
shield](/wiki/Captain_America%27s_shield#Marvel_Cinematic_Universe "Captain
America's shield"), and Thor's hammer [Mjolnir](/wiki/Mjolnir_\(comics\)
"Mjolnir \(comics\)"). Mendelson compared this to Disney's marketing campaign
for _[Lilo& Stitch](/wiki/Lilo_%26_Stitch "Lilo & Stitch")_ that put the
[protagonist](/wiki/Stitch_\(Lilo_%26_Stitch\) "Stitch \(Lilo & Stitch\)")
into iconic scenes from other Disney cartoons.[185] A six-minute IMAX preview
of the film began screeing before showings of _[Jurassic
World](/wiki/Jurassic_World "Jurassic World")_ ,[186] and scenes from the film
were shown at [Disney California Adventure](/wiki/Disney_California_Adventure
"Disney California Adventure")'s [Bug's Life
Theater](/wiki/It%27s_Tough_to_Be_a_Bug! "It's Tough to Be a Bug!") in 3D with
in-theater effects.[187]

In early July 2015, Marvel began a [viral marketing](/wiki/Viral_marketing
"Viral marketing") campaign featuring [Leslie Bibb](/wiki/Leslie_Bibb "Leslie
Bibb"), reprising her role from the _Iron Man_ films as journalist [Christine
Everhart](/wiki/Christine_Everhart "Christine Everhart"), reporting for the
faux news program _[WHIH Newsfront](/wiki/WHIH_Newsfront "WHIH Newsfront")_.
In the program, Everhart discuses the fallout from the events of _Avengers:
Age of Ultron_ , Lang's imprisonment,[188][189] and events leading to _Captain
America: Civil War_.[9] Also in July, Michael Douglas and executives from
[Marvel Entertainment](/wiki/Marvel_Entertainment "Marvel Entertainment") rang
the closing bell of the [New York Stock
Exchange](/wiki/New_York_Stock_Exchange "New York Stock Exchange") in
celebration of the release of _Ant-Man_.[190] Disney spent $34.8 million on
television advertising for the film, more than the $26.9 million spent for
_Avengers: Age of Ultron_ , since the former was a new property.[191]

In December 2015, to commemorate the home media release of _Ant-Man_ , [Marvel
UK](/wiki/Marvel_UK "Marvel UK") launched a website that offers visitors a
view of various London landmarks from the perspective of an ant in a [Google
Street View](/wiki/Google_Street_View "Google Street View")-type experience.
The company commissioned photographer Will Pearson to capture ten different
locations including [Tower Bridge](/wiki/Tower_Bridge "Tower Bridge"), [Oxford
Circus](/wiki/Oxford_Circus "Oxford Circus"), the [British
Museum](/wiki/British_Museum "British Museum"), [St Paul's
Cathedral](/wiki/St_Paul%27s_Cathedral "St Paul's Cathedral") and [Nelson's
Column](/wiki/Nelson%27s_Column "Nelson's Column") using a 360° miniature
camera that sat centimeters off of the ground.[192]

### Home media[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-
Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=12 "Edit section: Home media")]

_Ant-Man_ was released for [digital download](/wiki/Digital_distribution
"Digital distribution") by [Walt Disney Studios Home
Entertainment](/wiki/Walt_Disney_Studios_Home_Entertainment "Walt Disney
Studios Home Entertainment") on November 17, 2015 and released on [Blu-
ray](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc "Blu-ray Disc"), [Blu-ray 3D](/wiki/Blu-ray_Disc#Blu-
ray_3D "Blu-ray Disc"), and [DVD](/wiki/DVD "DVD") on December 8, 2015. The
digital and Blu-ray releases include behind-the-scenes featurettes, audio
commentary, deleted scenes, and a blooper reel.[193] Upon its first week of
release on home media in the U.S., the film debuted at number two on the
[Nielsen VideoScan](/wiki/Nielsen_VideoScan "Nielsen VideoScan") First Alert
chart, which tracks overall disc sales, as well as the dedicated Blu-ray Disc
sales chart, with 63% of unit sales coming from Blu-ray.[194]

The film was also collected in the 13-disc [box set](/wiki/Box_set "Box set"),
titled "[Marvel Cinematic Universe: Phase Two
Collection](/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films#Home_media "List of
Marvel Cinematic Universe films")", which includes all of the [Phase
Two](/wiki/List_of_Marvel_Cinematic_Universe_films#Phase_Two "List of Marvel
Cinematic Universe films") films in the Marvel Cinematic Universe. It was
released on December 8, 2015.[195]

## Reception[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Reception")]

### Box office[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-
Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=14 "Edit section: Box office")]

_Ant-Man_ grossed $180.2 million in North America and $339.1 million in other
territories for a worldwide total of $519.3 million.[3] _[Deadline
Hollywood](/wiki/Deadline_Hollywood "Deadline Hollywood")_ calculated the net
profit of the film to be $103.9 million, when factoring together "production
budgets, P&A, talent participations and other costs, with box office grosses,
and ancillary revenues from VOD to DVD and TV," placing it 14th on their list
of 2015's "Most Valuable Blockbusters".[196]

_Ant-Man_ made $6.4 million from its Thursday night showings in North America,
with 48% of tickets sales for IMAX and other large-format showings, and $23.4
million on its opening day, including Thursday's previews,[197] making it the
second-lowest opening day for a Marvel film, only ahead of 2008's _[The
Incredible Hulk](/wiki/The_Incredible_Hulk_\(film\) "The Incredible Hulk
\(film\)")_ ($21.4 million).[198] It fell 18% to earn $19.25 million on
Saturday, and for its opening weekend total, earned $57.2 million.[197][199]
It marked the second-lowest debut for Marvel ahead of the $55.4 million debut
of _The Incredible Hulk_ in 2008.[200] IMAX contributed $6.1 million to the
opening gross, with premium large format screens comprising $6.4 million and
[Cinemark XD](/wiki/Century_Theatres#XD "Century Theatres") comprising $1.3
million, respectively. Though the film fell below its $60 million estimate,
Disney nonetheless said it was content with the results, which continued
Marvel's streak of number one opening films, giving the studio its twelfth
consecutive win.[197] Disney also reported that the film drew the largest
share of families (28%) and women (32%) of any Marvel superhero title.[200] It
was also the biggest live-action opening ever for Rudd (breaking _[Knocked
Up](/wiki/Knocked_Up "Knocked Up")_ 's record of $30.7 million) and a record
opening for Douglas.[197] It continued to be the top film at the box office in
its second weekend.[201]

Outside North America, it earned $55.4 million in its opening weekend from 37
countries, debuting in third place at the international box office behind the
Chinese film _[Monster Hunt](/wiki/Monster_Hunt "Monster Hunt")_ and
_[Minions](/wiki/Minions_\(film\) "Minions \(film\)")_ as well as an IMAX
opening of $9.1 million. The top openings were the UK ($6 million), Mexico
($5.6 million), and Russia ($4.9 million). It had the biggest opening for a
first-installment Marvel film in Hong Kong, Indonesia, Malaysia, the
Philippines, Singapore, Taiwan, and Thailand.[202] The film's opening in South
Korea in early September 2015 earned $9.3 million, the highest opening for an
international market at the time,[203] before being surpassed by the Chinese
opening in mid-October 2015, which earned $42.4 million, with $5.1 million
coming from IMAX. The large opening weekend in China helped _Ant-Man_ place
first at the international box office for the first time, with the Chinese
opening the second largest for an MCU film in the country behind _Avengers:
Age of Ultron_.[204][205] The film stayed at number one in China for a second
week, earning an additional $22 million.[206] As of November 1,
2015[[update]](//en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Ant-
Man_\(film\)&action=edit), the largest markets are China with $101.3 million,
followed by the UK with $25.4 million, and South Korea with $18.9
million.[207][208]

### Critical response[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-
Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=15 "Edit section: Critical response")]

The [review aggregator](/wiki/Review_aggregator "Review aggregator") website
[Rotten Tomatoes](/wiki/Rotten_Tomatoes "Rotten Tomatoes") reported an 82%
approval rating, based on 287 reviews, with an average rating of 6.8/10. The
website's consensus reads, "Led by a charming performance from Paul Rudd,
_Ant-Man_ offers Marvel thrills on an appropriately smaller scale – albeit not
as smoothly as its most successful predecessors."[209] On
[Metacritic](/wiki/Metacritic "Metacritic"), the film has an average score of
64 out of 100, based on 43 critics, indicating "generally favorable
reviews".[210] [CinemaScore](/wiki/CinemaScore "CinemaScore") reported that
audiences gave the film an "A" grade on an A+ to F scale.[197]

Justin Chang of _[Variety](/wiki/Variety_\(magazine\) "Variety \(magazine\)")_
said the film "succeeds well enough as a genial diversion and sometimes a
delightful one, predicated on the rarely heeded Hollywood wisdom that less
really can be more."[211] [Todd McCarthy](/wiki/Todd_McCarthy "Todd McCarthy")
of _[The Hollywood Reporter](/wiki/The_Hollywood_Reporter "The Hollywood
Reporter")_ remarked, "Although the story dynamics are fundamentally silly and
the family stuff, with its parallel father-daughter melodrama, is elemental
button-pushing, a good cast led by a winning Paul Rudd puts the nonsense over
in reasonably disarming fashion."[212] [Kenneth Turan](/wiki/Kenneth_Turan
"Kenneth Turan") of the _[Los Angeles Times](/wiki/Los_Angeles_Times "Los
Angeles Times")_ wrote, "Playful in unexpected ways and graced with a
genuinely off-center sense of humor, _Ant-Man_ (engagingly directed by Peyton
Reed) is light on its feet the way the standard-issue Marvel behemoths never
are."[213] [Kim Newman](/wiki/Kim_Newman "Kim Newman") of
_[Empire](/wiki/Empire_\(film_magazine\) "Empire \(film magazine\)")_ wrote
that it "straddles as many genres as the Avengers films have characters but
manages to do most of them pretty well. Extremely likable, with a few moments
of proper wonder."[214] [A. O. Scott](/wiki/A._O._Scott "A. O. Scott") of
_[The New York Times](/wiki/The_New_York_Times "The New York Times")_ said,
"This film is a passable piece of drone work from the ever-expanding Marvel-
Disney colony."[215]

Conversely, Alonso Duralde of [TheWrap](/wiki/TheWrap "TheWrap") said the film
"serves up jokes that don't land and thrills that don't thrill."[216] [Richard
Roeper](/wiki/Richard_Roeper "Richard Roeper") of the _[Chicago Sun-
Times](/wiki/Chicago_Sun-Times "Chicago Sun-Times")_ said _Ant-Man_ "is a
lightweight, cliché-riddled origins story that veers between inside-joke
comedy, ponderous redemption story lines and admittedly nifty CGI sequences
that still seem relatively insignificant compared to the high stakes and city-
shattering destruction that take place in most of the _Avengers_ movies."[217]
Catherine Shoard of _[The Guardian](/wiki/The_Guardian "The Guardian")_ wrote,
"_Ant-Man_ is a cut-and-shut muddle, haunted by [Edgar Wright's] ghost,
produced by a high-end hot dog factory, by turns giddying and
stupefying."[218] Joe Morgenstern of _[The Wall Street
Journal](/wiki/The_Wall_Street_Journal "The Wall Street Journal")_ said that
it is "a film that will surely be popular, given Marvel's marketing might, but
one that's woefully short on coherence and originality."[219] [Christopher
Orr](/wiki/Christopher_Orr_\(film_critic\) "Christopher Orr \(film critic\)")
of _[The Atlantic](/wiki/The_Atlantic "The Atlantic")_ said, "It's difficult
to shake the sense that the film was assembled hurriedly and somewhat
haphazardly. Which, from all available evidence, is exactly what
happened."[220]

## Sequel[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Ant-Man_\(film\)&action=edit&section=17
"Edit section: Sequel")]

Main article: [Ant-Man and the Wasp](/wiki/Ant-Man_and_the_Wasp "Ant-Man and
the Wasp")

A sequel, _Ant-Man and the Wasp_ is scheduled to be released on July 6, 2018,
with Reed once again returning as director. Production writers Barrer and
Ferrari also return to write the screenplay with Rudd, [Chris
McKenna](/wiki/Chris_McKenna_\(writer\) "Chris McKenna \(writer\)") and Erik
Sommers. Rudd, Lilly, Cannavale, Peña, Harris, Greer, Dastmalchian, Fortson
and Douglas all reprise their roles from _Ant-Man_ ,[231] and are joined by
[Michelle Pfeiffer](/wiki/Michelle_Pfeiffer "Michelle Pfeiffer"), [Laurence
Fishburne](/wiki/Laurence_Fishburne "Laurence Fishburne"), [Hannah John-
Kamen](/wiki/Hannah_John-Kamen "Hannah John-Kamen"), [Randall
Park](/wiki/Randall_Park "Randall Park") and [Walton
Goggins](/wiki/Walton_Goggins "Walton Goggins") as Janet van Dyne, [Bill
Foster](/wiki/Bill_Foster_\(comics\) "Bill Foster \(comics\)"),
[Ghost](/wiki/Ghost_\(Marvel_Comics\) "Ghost \(Marvel Comics\)"), [Jimmy
Woo](/wiki/Jimmy_Woo "Jimmy Woo"), and [Sonny Burch](/wiki/Sonny_Burch "Sonny
Burch"), respectively.[232][231]
